document.docAuthor: Albino, Jeyson Lazaro Duque, Pes, Ana Maria & Hamada, Neusa
document.docTitle: Smicridea (Rhyacophylax) helenae Albino, Pes & Hamada, 2011, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Smicridea (Trichoptera, Hydropsychidae) from 3 Brazilian Amazonian States: New species, larval taxonomy and bionomics

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Smicridea (Trichoptera, Hydropsychidae) from 3 Brazilian Amazonian States: New species, larval taxonomy and bionomics

figureCitation.captionText-1: FIGURES 34 – 37. Smicridea (Rhyacophylax) helenae sp. nov. male genitalia. 34) Left lateral view; 35) dorsal view; 36) phallus retracted, dorsal view; 37) phallus expanded, ventral view.

Smicridea (Rhyacophylax) helenae sp. nov. pupae. 38) Dorsal view; 39) labrum, dorsal view; 40) mandibles, dorsal view; 41) abdominal segments IX – X, dorsal view; 42) hook plates (2 – 8 = abdominal segment number, a = anterior, p = posterior), dorsal view.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 32–33.
Smicridea ( Rhyacophylax ) helenae
sp. nov.
31) Male right forewing, dorsal view, scale bar = 500 µ; 32) sternum V, ventral view, showing anterolateral glandular processes, scale bar = 100 µ.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Larva (
Figs 43–51
). Length 4.5–6 mm (n = 5 ). Color in alcohol, yellow (recently collected larvae whitish, with brown setae) lateral habitus as in
Figure 43
; body covered with short, spatulate setae.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 34–37.
Smicridea ( Rhyacophylax ) helenae
sp. nov.
male genitalia. 34) Left lateral view; 35) dorsal view; 36) phallus retracted, dorsal view; 37) phallus expanded, ventral view.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Diagnosis. The male of
S. helenae
sp. nov.
differs from those of the other species described in the subgenus by having tergum X with its distal region narrow and truncated in lateral view. The phallus has the internal sclerotized region of the ejaculatory duct wide distally and reticulated apically, divided longitudinally in 2 parts and diverging at both apical and basal ends; the endothecal membranes have a pair of sclerotized lateral paramere spines that are dark distally and terminated apically with short spines.

The pupa of
S. helenae
sp. nov.
differs from those of the other species described in the subgenus by having the basolateral regions of the labrum a little shorter than the central lobe. Furthermore, the lateral lobes of the labrum in the new species each has 4 long setae and the central lobe has 5 medium setae. The pupa of the new species also differs from those of the other species by having hook plates on segments as described below and by differences in the form and number of hook plates; for
S. helenae ,
in hook-plate pair 2 a each plate has 2 strong hooks, while for
S . appendiculata
in hook-plate pair 2 a each plate bears 5 strong hooks; for
S . dithyra
, in hook-plate pair 2 a each plate has 8 strong hooks and 5 small ones, and for
S. pampeana
, in hook-plate pair 2 a each plate has 6 strong and 5 small hooks.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 38–42.
Smicridea ( Rhyacophylax ) helenae
sp. nov.
pupae. 38) Dorsal view; 39) labrum, dorsal view; 40) mandibles, dorsal view; 41) abdominal segments IX–X, dorsal view; 42) hook plates (2–8 = abdominal segment number, a = anterior, p = posterior), dorsal view.

subSubSection.paragraph: The larva can be distinguished from those of the other species in the subgenus by the rounded shape of the head, the dark triangular spot on the posterior region of the frontoclypeus, and the narrow stridulation files ventrally on the genae, each with thin striations that are lightly marked.

Biology. Adults of
S. helenae
sp. nov.
were collected with light traps placed over streams and rivers ( 1 in Roraima; 1 in Amazonas; 7 in Mato Grosso) with widths ranging from 4.5 to 1500 m . Larvae and pupae were collected in the Rio Branco, 1200 m in width, white water, pH 7.8 , with boulders and rubble in riffle areas with Podostemaceae plants, located in savanna and in transitional areas between savanna and Amazonian rain forest; larvae were also collected in the Rio Negro, 1500 m in width, black water, pH 4.5 , with rubble in riffle areas with Podostemaceae plants, located in Amazon Forest. In the state of Mato Grosso this species was collected in preserved gallery forest in the Cerrado biome; in the state of Amazonas adults were collected in a tributary of the Rio Negro, with acidic black water.
Distribution. Brazil Roraima, Mato Grosso and Amazonas states.

Etymology. The name
helenae
is in honor of Dr Helena Soares Ramos Cabette (UNEMAT), for her great contributions to the study of aquatic insects.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 43–48.
Smicridea ( Rhyacophylax ) helenae
sp. nov.
larva. 43) Right lateral view; 44) head, dorsal view; 45) head, ventral view; 46) head, right lateral view; 47) right side of head, ventral view, showing the stridulation structure; 48) thorax, dorsal view.

FIGURES 49–51.
Smicridea ( Rhyacophylax ) helenae
sp. nov.
larva. 49) Mandibles dorsal view; 50) labrum, dorsal view; 51) ventral sclerites on abdominal segments VIII–X, ventral view.
